column4: is a city in Lower Saxony

column1: A powerful and influential centre of commerce in medieval Germany
column2: Brunswick was a member of the Hanseatic League from the 13th until the 17th century. It was the capital city of three successive states: the Principality of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel (1269–1432
column5: the Duchy of Brunswick (1814–1918)
column6: and the Free State of Brunswick (1918–1946).

column2: Brunswick is the second-largest city in Lower Saxony and a major centre of scientific research and development.

column1: The date and circumstances of the town's foundation are unknown. Tradition maintains that Brunswick was created through the merger of two settlements
column3: a Saxon count who died in 880
column4: on one side of the River Oker – the legend gives the year 861 for the foundation – and the other the settlement of a legendary Count Dankward
column5: after whom Dankwarderode Castle ("Dankward's clearing")
column6: which was reconstructed in the 19th century
column7: is named. The town's original name of Brunswik is a combination of the name Bruno and Low German wik (related to the Latin vicus)
column8: a place where merchants rested and stored their goods. The town's name
column11: as it lay by a ford across the Oker River. Another explanation of the city's name is that it comes from Brand
column13: indicating a place which developed after the landscape was cleared through burning. The city was first mentioned in documents from the St. Magni Church from 1031
column14: which give the city's name as Brunesguik.

column1: === Middle Ages and early modern period ===

column2: Brunswick was ruled by the Saxon noble family of the Brunonids
column5: it fell to the House of Welf. In 1142
column6: Henry the Lion of the House of Welf became duke of Saxony and made Braunschweig the capital of his state (which
column7: from 1156 on
column8: also included the Duchy of Bavaria). He turned Dankwarderode Castle
column9: the residence of the counts of Brunswick
column10: into his own Pfalz and developed the city further to represent his authority. Under Henry's rule
column11: the Cathedral of St. Blasius was built and he also had the statue of a lion
column13: erected in front of the castle. The lion subsequently became the city's landmark.

column1: Henry the Lion became so powerful that he dared to refuse military aid to the Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa
column2: which led to his banishment in 1182. Henry went into exile in England. He had previously established ties to the English crown in 1168
column3: through his marriage to King Henry II of England's daughter Matilda
column4: sister of Richard the Lionheart. However
column5: his son Otto
column6: who could regain influence and was eventually crowned Holy Roman Emperor
column7: continued to foster the city's development.

column2: Brunswick was an important center of trade
column3: one of the economic and political centers in Northern Europe and a member of the Hanseatic League from the 13th century to the middle of the 17th century. By the year 1600
column4: Brunswick was the seventh largest city in Germany. Although formally one of the residences of the rulers of the Duchy of Brunswick-Lüneburg
column5: a constituent state of the Holy Roman Empire
column6: Brunswick was de facto ruled independently by a powerful class of patricians and the guilds throughout much of the Late Middle Ages and the Early modern period. Because of the growing power of Brunswick's burghers
column7: the Princes of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel
column8: who ruled over one of the subdivisions of Brunswick-Lüneburg
column9: finally moved their Residenz out of the city and to the nearby town of Wolfenbüttel in 1432. The Princes of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel didn't regain control over the city until the late 17th century
column12: took the city by siege. In the 18th century Brunswick was not only a political
column13: but also a cultural centre. Influenced by the philosophy of the Enlightenment
column14: dukes like Anthony Ulrich and Charles I became patrons of the arts and sciences. In 1745 Charles I founded the Collegium Carolinum
column15: predecessor of the Brunswick University of a Technology
column16: and in 1753 he moved the ducal residence back to Brunswick. With this he attracted poets and thinkers such as Lessing
column18: and Jakob Mauvillon to his court and the city. Emilia Galotti by Lessing and Goethe's Faust were performed for the first time in Brunswick.

column2: the city was captured by the French during the Napoleonic Wars and became part of the short-lived Napoleonic Kingdom of Westphalia in 1807. The exiled Duke Frederick William raised a volunteer corps
column4: who fought the French in several battles.After the Congress of Vienna in 1815
column5: Brunswick was made capital of the re-established independent Duchy of Brunswick
column6: later a constituent state of the German Empire from 1871. In the aftermath of the July Revolution in 1830
column7: in Brunswick duke Charles II was forced to abdicate. His absolutist governing style had previously alienated the nobility and bourgeoisie
column8: while the lower classes were disaffected by the bad economic situation. During the night of 7–8 September 1830
column9: the ducal palace in Brunswick was stormed by an angry mob
column11: and destroyed completely. Charles was succeeded by his brother William VIII. During William's reign
column12: liberal reforms were made and Brunswick's parliament was strengthened.During the 19th century
column13: industrialisation caused a rapid growth of population in the city
column14: eventually causing Brunswick to be for the first time significantly enlarged beyond its medieval fortifications and the River Oker. On 1 December 1838
column15: the first section of the Brunswick–Bad Harzburg railway line connecting Brunswick and Wolfenbüttel opened as the first railway line in Northern Germany
column16: operated by the Duchy of Brunswick State Railway.

column2: at the end of World War I
column3: a socialist workers' council forced Duke Ernest Augustus to abdicate. On 10 November
column4: the council proclaimed the Socialist Republic of Brunswick under one-party government by the Independent Social Democratic Party of Germany (USPD); however
column5: the subsequent Landtag election on 22 December 1918 was won by the Social Democratic Party of Germany (MSPD)
column6: and the USPD and MSPD formed a coalition government. An uprising in Braunschweig in 1919
column7: led by the communist Spartacus League
column8: was defeated when Freikorps troops under Georg Ludwig Rudolf Maercker took over the city on order of the German Minister of Defence
column9: Gustav Noske. An SPD-led government was subsequently established; in December 1921
column10: a new constitution was approved for the Free State of Brunswick
column11: now a parliamentary republic within the Weimar Republic
column12: again with Braunschweig as its capital.After the Landtag election of 1930
column13: Brunswick became the second state in Germany where the Nazis participated in government
column14: when the National Socialist German Workers' Party (NSDAP) formed a coalition government with several conservative and right-wing parties. With the support of Dietrich Klagges
column16: the NSDAP organized a large SA rally in Braunschweig. On 17–18 October 1931
column18: 000 SA stormtroopers marched through the city
column21: and communists left several dead or injured. On 25 February 1932
column22: the state of Brunswick granted Adolf Hitler German citizenship to allow him to run in the 1932 German presidential election. In Braunschweig
column23: Nazis carried out several attacks on political enemies
column24: with the acquiescence of the state government.After the Nazi seizure of power in 1933
column25: several state institutions were placed in Braunschweig
column27: the Hitler Youth Academy for Youth Leadership
column28: and the SS-Junkerschule Braunschweig. With the Reichswerke Hermann Göring in Salzgitter and the Stadt des KdF-Wagens
column29: as well as several factories in the city itself (including Büssing and the Volkswagenwerk Braunschweig)
column30: the Braunschweig region became one of the centres of the German arms industry.During the Second World War
column31: Braunschweig was an Untergebiet Hauptquartier ("Sub-Area Headquarters") of Wehrkreis XI ("Military District XI")
column32: and was the garrison city of the 31st Infantry Division that took part in the invasions of Poland
column35: largely being destroyed during its retreat following the invasion of Russia. In this period
column36: thousands of Eastern workers were brought to the city as forced labor
column37: and in the 1943–1945 period at least 360 children taken away from such workers died in the Entbindungsheim für Ostarbeiterinnen ("Maternity Ward for Eastern Workers").In 1944
column38: a subcamp of the concentration camp Neuengamme was established in Braunschweig.  Hundreds of prisoners
column40: lived in brutal conditions and hundreds died from hunger
column44: writes of her imprisonment in that camp in her book
column46: published in English in 2006 by MacMillan Palgrave.

Many other geographical locations around the world are named Brunswick
column2: after the historical English name of Braunschweig. Between 1714 and 1837
column3: the House of Hanover ruled Great Britain in personal union with the Electorate of Hanover. The House of Hanover was formally known as the House of Brunswick-Lüneburg
column5: many places in the British colonies were named after Brunswick
column6: such as the province of New Brunswick in Canada.Ironically
column7: the city of Braunschweig was not ruled by the Hanoverians while its name was being given to other Brunswicks around the world. Starting in 1269
column8: the Duchy of Brunswick-Lüneburg underwent a series of divisions and mergers
column9: with parts of the territory being transferred between various branches of the family. The city of Braunschweig went to the senior branch of the house
column11: while Lüneburg eventually ended up with the Hanover line. Although the territory had been split
column12: all branches of the family continued to style themselves as the House of Brunswick-Lüneburg. In 1884
column13: the senior branch of the House of Welf became extinct. The Hanover line
column14: being the last surviving line of the family
column15: subsequently held the throne of the Duchy of Brunswick from November 1913 until November 1918.
